articles.title: How to Write an Effective Resume for Tech Jobs
articles.body:
A well-crafted resume is essential for making a strong first impression in the tech industry. Recruiters often spend only a few seconds scanning a resume, so it's crucial to make yours stand out. A strong resume should not only showcase your technical skills but also demonstrate how you can add value to an organization.

Why Your Resume Matters

Your resume is often the first thing hiring managers see before they decide to interview you. A well-structured resume:

  • Helps you stand out in a competitive job market.
  • Demonstrates your qualifications and experience clearly.
  • Passes Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) that filter resumes before a recruiter even sees them.

Best Practices for Writing a Resume

  • Keep it concise and relevant: Aim for a one-page resume if you have less than 10 years of experience; two pages if you have significant experience.
  • Use a professional layout: A simple, well-structured format with a clear hierarchy of information makes it easy to scan.
  • Highlight technical skills: List programming languages, frameworks, and tools you are proficient in. Create a dedicated 'Skills' section for clarity.
  • Showcase achievements: Instead of listing responsibilities, use quantifiable metrics to showcase impact (e.g., 'Increased test coverage by 40% within 6 months').
  • Customize for each job: Tailor your resume by using keywords from the job description and focusing on relevant experiences.
  • Use action words: Start bullet points with strong verbs like 'Developed,' 'Implemented,' 'Optimized,' 'Designed,' or 'Led.'
  • Proofread and edit: Spelling or grammatical mistakes can create a negative impression. Use tools like Grammarly for accuracy.

Key Sections to Include

Your resume should have the following sections:

  • Contact Information: Include your full name, phone number, professional email, LinkedIn profile, GitHub (if applicable), and location (city, state/country).
  • Summary: A brief 2-3 sentence overview highlighting your skills, experience, and career goals.
  • Work Experience: List past roles, responsibilities, and achievements with quantifiable results.
  • Education: Degree(s), certifications, and relevant coursework. Mention any technical boot camps if applicable.
  • Projects: Include personal, freelance, or open-source projects that demonstrate your skills and problem-solving ability.
  • Certifications and Training: If applicable, list certifications like AWS Certified Developer, ISTQB, or Google Cloud certifications.

Additional Tips

  • Use a standard font like Arial, Calibri, or Times New Roman (10-12pt size).
  • Avoid adding unnecessary graphics or images, as they can be difficult for ATS to process.
  • Save your resume as a PDF to maintain formatting.
  • Include relevant keywords from the job description to pass ATS filters.

By following these best practices, you can craft a compelling resume that increases your chances of landing an interview in the tech industry.

articles.title: Top 5 Mistakes to Avoid in Job Interviews
articles.body:
Job interviews can be nerve-wracking, but avoiding common mistakes can significantly improve your chances of success. A strong interview is not just about answering questions correctly but also about demonstrating confidence, professionalism, and enthusiasm for the role.

Top Interview Mistakes

  • Not researching the company: Failing to learn about the company’s mission, culture, and recent projects can make you appear unprepared. Review their website, LinkedIn, and any recent press releases before the interview.
  • Speaking negatively about past employers: Even if you had a bad experience at a previous job, avoid negativity. Instead, focus on what you learned and how it prepared you for this new opportunity.
  • Failing to ask questions: Interviews are a two-way conversation. Asking insightful questions shows your interest in the role and helps you determine if the company is the right fit for you.
  • Giving unstructured answers: Avoid rambling or going off-topic. Use the STAR method (Situation, Task, Action, Result) to structure your responses and clearly highlight your contributions.
  • Dressing inappropriately: Even for remote interviews, dressing professionally creates a strong first impression. Research the company’s dress code and aim to dress slightly more formal than their standard attire.

Additional Interview Tips

  • Practice answering common technical and behavioral questions.
  • Prepare a 30-second elevator pitch about your background, skills, and why you're excited about the role.
  • Follow up with a thank-you email to reiterate your interest in the position.
  • Maintain good posture, eye contact, and a positive attitude throughout the conversation.

By avoiding these mistakes and preparing thoroughly, you can make a lasting impression and increase your chances of getting hired.

articles.title: How to Stand Out as a Junior Developer
articles.body:
Breaking into the tech industry as a junior developer can be challenging, but there are several strategies to make yourself stand out and increase your chances of getting hired.

How to Differentiate Yourself

  • Build a portfolio: Showcase your best projects on GitHub or a personal website. Include live demos and detailed documentation.
  • Contribute to open-source projects: Collaborate with experienced developers, gain real-world experience, and build your credibility.
  • Network effectively: Attend meetups, tech conferences, and engage in online developer communities on LinkedIn, Twitter, and Discord.
  • Keep learning: Stay updated with the latest programming languages, frameworks, and industry trends through courses, podcasts, and blogs.
  • Prepare for coding interviews: Practice algorithmic problems on LeetCode and HackerRank. Learn system design basics and problem-solving techniques.

Key Skills for Junior Developers

In addition to coding, companies value:

  • Strong problem-solving and critical-thinking abilities.
  • Understanding of version control systems like Git and GitHub.
  • Basic knowledge of databases, APIs, and deployment tools.
  • Soft skills like teamwork, communication, and adaptability.

By consistently improving your skills, building relationships, and showcasing your work, you can stand out as a junior developer and land your first tech job.

articles.title: How to Prepare for a Manual Testing Interview
articles.body:
Preparing for a manual testing interview requires a solid understanding of software testing concepts, tools, and real-world scenarios. Companies assess candidates based on theoretical knowledge, practical experience, and problem-solving skills.

Key Areas to Focus On

  • Testing Fundamentals: Understand the basics of functional testing, non-functional testing, black-box testing, white-box testing, and regression testing.
  • Bug Life Cycle: Be able to explain the different states of a bug and how it is tracked from detection to closure.
  • Test Case Design: Learn how to write effective test cases using boundary value analysis, equivalence partitioning, and exploratory testing techniques.
  • Test Plan and Strategy: Be familiar with test plan components, entry and exit criteria, test objectives, and risk management strategies.
  • Defect Reporting: Demonstrate your ability to log clear and concise bug reports with proper reproduction steps and expected vs. actual results.

Common Manual Testing Interview Questions

  • What is the difference between severity and priority in bug tracking?
  • How do you handle a situation where a developer does not agree with a reported bug?
  • Explain the importance of boundary value testing with an example.
  • What are the key components of a test case?
  • How do you ensure test coverage in a time-constrained project?

By focusing on these areas and practicing real-world scenarios, you can confidently approach a manual testing interview.

articles.title: Technical Interview Tips for Automation Testers
articles.body:
Automation testing interviews often involve coding challenges, framework design discussions, and tool-based problem-solving. Proper preparation can help you stand out.

Important Topics to Prepare

  • Programming Skills: Be proficient in a scripting or programming language such as Java, Python, or JavaScript.
  • Selenium and Playwright: Understand locators, handling dynamic elements, page object models, and headless execution.
  • Test Automation Frameworks: Be familiar with frameworks like TestNG, JUnit, Cypress, and WebDriverIO.
  • CI/CD and DevOps: Understand how automated tests fit into a continuous integration and delivery pipeline.
  • API Testing: Learn API validation techniques using Postman, RestAssured, or Playwright.

Common Automation Testing Interview Questions

  • What are the advantages of using Selenium over other automation tools?
  • How do you handle dynamic web elements in automation?
  • What is the difference between implicit and explicit waits?
  • Explain the Page Object Model (POM) and its benefits.
  • How do you integrate test automation into a CI/CD pipeline?

By sharpening your coding and automation framework knowledge, you can increase your chances of succeeding in an automation testing interview.

articles.title: How to Ace a QA Behavioral Interview
articles.body:
Behavioral interviews for QA roles assess your problem-solving approach, teamwork skills, and ability to handle real-world testing challenges.

Common Behavioral Questions and How to Answer

  • Tell me about a time you found a critical defect before release. Explain how you identified the issue, collaborated with developers, and ensured a fix before deployment.
  • Describe a situation where you had to work under tight deadlines. Highlight how you prioritized testing tasks and focused on high-risk areas first.
  • How do you handle conflicts with developers regarding a defect? Emphasize communication, data-driven discussions, and mutual goal alignment.
  • Have you ever proposed a process improvement? Discuss how you introduced automation, improved test coverage, or enhanced test case management.
  • Tell me about a time you had to learn a new testing tool quickly. Share how you adapted and upskilled yourself in a short period.

Tips for Success

  • Use the STAR method (Situation, Task, Action, Result) to structure responses.
  • Provide specific examples rather than generic answers.
  • Demonstrate a problem-solving mindset and willingness to learn.

By preparing well-structured responses, you can confidently tackle behavioral interview questions in a QA interview.

articles.title: How to Answer Agile and Scrum Questions in a QA Interview
articles.body:
Many companies follow Agile methodologies, so QA testers should be prepared to answer questions about Agile and Scrum frameworks in interviews.

Key Agile and Scrum Concepts

  • Scrum Roles: Be familiar with the roles of Product Owner, Scrum Master, and Development Team.
  • Scrum Ceremonies: Understand daily stand-ups, sprint planning, backlog refinement, sprint reviews, and retrospectives.
  • Testers in Agile: Explain how QA integrates into Agile teams and contributes to continuous testing.
  • Test Automation in Agile: Discuss how automation fits into sprint cycles and helps in regression testing.

Common Agile QA Interview Questions

  • What challenges do testers face in Agile?
  • How do you handle incomplete requirements in Agile testing?
  • How do you ensure testing keeps up with rapid development?
  • What is the role of test automation in Agile?
  • How do you handle last-minute requirement changes?

Tips for Answering Agile Questions

  • Showcase adaptability and teamwork.
  • Provide examples of real-world Agile testing experiences.
  • Demonstrate an understanding of iterative development and continuous testing.

By preparing for Agile-specific questions, you can confidently answer interview questions about testing in Agile environments.

articles.title: How to Prepare for a Whiteboard Coding Challenge as a Tester
articles.body:
Some QA interviews include whiteboard coding exercises to assess problem-solving skills and basic programming knowledge. Even for manual testers, companies may test logical thinking and basic scripting.

Common Whiteboard Challenges for Testers

  • String Manipulation: Reverse a string, find duplicates, or count vowels.
  • Array and List Operations: Find the largest/smallest number, remove duplicates, or sort arrays.
  • Conditional Logic: Write a function to determine if a number is prime.
  • Simple Automation Script: Write pseudocode for automating a login flow.
  • SQL Queries: Retrieve the second-highest salary or filter records by date.

How to Approach Whiteboard Challenges

  • Clarify the problem before writing code.
  • Break the solution into smaller, logical steps.
  • Use meaningful variable names and clean syntax.
  • Explain your thought process while coding.
  • Optimize the solution for efficiency.

By practicing coding problems in advance, you can approach whiteboard challenges with confidence.

articles.title: How to Handle Tricky Situational Questions in a QA Interview
articles.body:
Situational questions in QA interviews assess how you respond to real-world challenges. Interviewers want to see how you think under pressure and handle difficult situations.

Common Situational Questions and How to Answer

  • You found a critical defect just before release. What do you do? Discuss risk assessment, stakeholder communication, and decision-making.
  • A developer dismisses a defect you reported. How do you handle it? Explain how you use logs, screenshots, and test data to justify your report.
  • You have to test a feature with vague requirements. How do you proceed? Emphasize exploratory testing, collaboration, and asking clarifying questions.
  • Your team has no formal testing process. What would you suggest? Talk about introducing test cases, automation, and documentation gradually.
  • How do you handle tight deadlines and multiple priorities? Discuss risk-based testing, prioritization, and efficient test execution.

Best Practices for Situational Questions

  • Use the STAR (Situation, Task, Action, Result) method for clear answers.
  • Provide real-life examples from past projects.
  • Demonstrate problem-solving and communication skills.

By preparing for these tricky questions, you can confidently handle challenging scenarios in a QA interview.

articles.title: How to Answer Playwright Automation Questions in a QA Interview
articles.body:
Playwright is gaining popularity as a modern end-to-end testing tool for web applications. Interviewers often ask about its capabilities, architecture, and best practices.

Key Playwright Topics to Prepare

  • What is Playwright? Explain how it enables cross-browser testing for Chromium, Firefox, and WebKit.
  • Playwright vs. Selenium: Discuss key differences, such as speed, auto-wait mechanisms, and built-in assertions.
  • Locators in Playwright: Understand CSS, XPath, text selectors, and the best strategies for defining reliable locators.
  • Handling Dynamic Elements: Use `waitForSelector()`, auto-waiting, and retry mechanisms.
  • Parallel Test Execution: Explain how Playwright’s built-in worker processes improve test speed.

Common Playwright Interview Questions

  • How does Playwright handle flaky tests?
  • What are the benefits of using Playwright over Cypress or Selenium?
  • How do you capture screenshots and videos in Playwright?
  • Explain how Playwright supports API testing.
  • How do you integrate Playwright tests with CI/CD pipelines?

Best Practices for Answering Playwright Questions

  • Demonstrate knowledge of Playwright’s auto-waiting and retry mechanisms.
  • Provide examples of handling authentication, file uploads, and visual testing.
  • Be ready to explain how to structure Playwright tests for scalability.

By mastering Playwright concepts, you can confidently handle automation-related questions in your QA interview.

articles.title: Advanced Playwright Features You Should Know for Interviews
articles.body:
For senior QA roles, interviewers expect candidates to be familiar with advanced Playwright features that improve automation efficiency and maintainability.

Advanced Topics in Playwright

  • Custom Test Assertions: Learn how to extend Playwright’s `expect()` API for custom validations.
  • Mocking APIs in Playwright: Understand how to intercept network requests using `page.route()`.
  • Using Fixtures in Playwright: Explain how Playwright fixtures can improve test data setup.
  • Handling WebSockets and GraphQL: Describe how Playwright interacts with real-time data flows.
  • Performance Testing with Playwright: Learn how to measure page load time and response times.

Common Advanced Playwright Questions

  • How do you use Playwright’s API mocking feature?
  • What is the best way to handle authentication across multiple tests?
  • How do you measure page load performance in Playwright?
  • What strategies do you use to make Playwright tests run faster?
  • How does Playwright handle mobile and responsive testing?

Tips for Answering Advanced Playwright Questions

  • Explain your approach to improving test stability and performance.
  • Show how Playwright can be integrated with Jest, Mocha, or custom test runners.
  • Be prepared to discuss Playwright’s headless and headed execution modes.

By understanding these advanced topics, you can stand out in Playwright-focused automation interviews.

articles.title: How to Structure Playwright Automation Tests for Scalability
articles.body:
Scalability is a key consideration for Playwright test automation. Interviewers often ask about structuring test projects for maintainability and efficiency.

Best Practices for Structuring Playwright Tests

  • Using Page Object Model (POM): Implement reusable page classes for better test maintainability.
  • Test Data Management: Store test data in JSON, YAML, or environment variables.
  • Parallel Execution: Optimize test runs using Playwright’s built-in parallelization features.
  • Custom Helper Methods: Abstract repetitive actions into reusable functions.
  • Logging and Reporting: Integrate Allure, TestRail, or Playwright’s built-in tracing feature.

Common Playwright Test Structure Interview Questions

  • How do you implement the Page Object Model in Playwright?
  • What is the best way to manage test data in Playwright?
  • How do you run Playwright tests in parallel, and what are the benefits?
  • How do you organize large Playwright test suites?
  • What reporting tools work well with Playwright?

How to Answer Scalability Questions

  • Provide examples of structuring Playwright projects in real-world applications.
  • Discuss Playwright’s support for multi-threaded test execution.
  • Show how to reduce flakiness by implementing best practices for stable locators.

By understanding scalable test architecture in Playwright, you can effectively showcase your automation expertise in interviews.

articles.title: How to Handle Authentication in Playwright Automation Tests
articles.body:
Authentication is a crucial part of automated testing, and Playwright provides various ways to handle login sessions effectively.

Common Authentication Scenarios in Playwright

  • Persistent Login: Save login sessions to avoid repeated authentication.
  • Handling Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Automate OTP, email verification, or SMS authentication.
  • API-Based Authentication: Use API requests to authenticate before launching the UI.

Using Storage State for Persistent Login

Playwright allows saving and reusing authentication state to speed up test execution:

const { test, expect } = require('@playwright/test'); test.use({ storageState: 'auth.json' }); test('Verify user is logged in', async ({ page }) => {
await page.goto('https://example.com/dashboard');
await expect(page.locator('text=Welcome, User')).toBeVisible(); });

Using API Authentication

Authenticate via API and store session cookies:

const { request } = require('@playwright/test');
test('Login via API', async ({ page, context }) => {
const apiRequest = await request.newContext();
const response = await apiRequest.post('https://example.com/api/login', { data: { username: 'user', password: 'pass' } });
const cookies = await apiRequest.cookies();
await context.addCookies(cookies);
await page.goto('https://example.com/dashboard'); });

Common Interview Questions on Authentication

  • How do you persist login state in Playwright?
  • How would you handle authentication in CI/CD environments?
  • What are the challenges of testing authentication flows?

articles.title: How to Handle File Uploads and Downloads in Playwright
articles.body:
File upload and download operations are common in web applications. Playwright offers built-in APIs to handle these scenarios effectively.

Handling File Uploads

Use the `setInputFiles()` method to automate file uploads:

const { test, expect } = require('@playwright/test'); 
test('Upload a file', async ({ page }) => {
await page.goto('https://example.com/upload');
await page.setInputFiles('input[type=file]', 'uploads/sample.pdf');
await expect(page.locator('.upload-success')).toBeVisible(); });

Handling File Downloads

Use the `page.waitForEvent('download')` method to handle file downloads:

test('Download a file', async ({ page }) => {
await page.goto('https://example.com/download');
const [download] = await Promise.all([
page.waitForEvent('download'), page.click('.download-btn') ]);
const filePath = await download.path();
console.log(`File downloaded to: ${filePath}`); });

Common Interview Questions on File Handling

  • How do you test file uploads in Playwright?
  • How do you verify file contents after a download?
  • What are the challenges of handling large file uploads?

articles.title: How to Mock API Responses in Playwright for Reliable Testing
articles.body:
Mocking API responses is essential when testing applications that rely on backend services. Playwright provides `page.route()` to intercept and modify network requests.

Mocking API Responses

Intercept network requests and return a mocked response:

const { test, expect } = require('@playwright/test');
test('Mock API response', async ({ page }) => {
await page.route('https://api.example.com/data', async route => {
await route.fulfill({ status: 200,
contentType: 'application/json', body: JSON.stringify({ message: 'Mocked Response' }) }); });
await page.goto('https://example.com');
await expect(page.locator('.api-message')).toHaveText('Mocked Response'); });

Mocking API Failures

Simulate server errors to test error handling:

test('Mock API failure', async ({ page }) => {
await page.route('https://api.example.com/data', async route => {
await route.fulfill({ status: 500, body: 'Internal Server Error' }); });
await page.goto('https://example.com');
await expect(page.locator('.error-message')).toBeVisible(); });

Common Interview Questions on API Mocking

  • How do you mock API requests in Playwright?
  • When should you use API mocking instead of real requests?
  • How do you simulate different API response statuses?

books.description: An enchanting tale of a mystical clock that controls the passage of time, and the three guardians sworn to protect its secrets from falling into the wrong hands.

books.description: A riveting adventure into a world where coding shapes reality, and a group of renegades fight to uncover the truth behind the mysterious Shadow Algorithm.

books.title: Sands of the Infinite
books.description: A young prince must traverse a desert world filled with ancient ruins and warring factions to find the mythical Sands of the Infinite and secure peace for his people.

books.title: Legends of the Crystal Keep
books.description: An epic saga of heroes, magic, and betrayal, set in a world where the Crystal Keep holds the power to reshape destiny itself.

books.title: The Cosmic Voyage
books.description: A comedic yet profound journey through the galaxy, exploring the absurdities of life, love, and the universe with a hapless captain and his misfit crew.

books.title: The Iron Veil
books.description: A dystopian tale of a world divided by an unbreakable iron curtain, where one woman dares to uncover the truth behind the regime’s iron grip.

books.title: Rebellion of the Lost Meadow
books.description: In a hidden meadow, creatures rise against their oppressors in a stirring allegory of freedom, equality, and the cost of revolution.

books.title: Echoes of Redemption
books.description: A harrowing journey of a man seeking forgiveness in the shadows of a crime that reshaped his destiny, set against a backdrop of philosophical turmoil.

books.title: The House of the Eternal Flame
books.description: A gripping tale of family, faith, and betrayal in 19th-century Russia, where the discovery of an eternal flame challenges their beliefs and bonds.

books.title: The Last Chronicle of Stars
books.description: In the distant future, humanity’s remnants compete for survival among the stars, while an ancient artifact threatens to unearth long-forgotten truths.

books.title: The Alchemist's Labyrinth
books.description: An inventor discovers a labyrinthine world of alchemical wonders and perilous traps, where he must master ancient knowledge to find his lost apprentice.

books.title: Commanders of the Eternal Horizon
books.description: Two military leaders recount their experiences defending humanity from an enigmatic alien race, blending strategy, courage, and the weight of command.

books.title: The Battle of Celestial Shores
books.description: A short yet profound tale of an ancient warrior facing cosmic forces on the shores of an uncharted planet, blending myth and science fiction.

books.title: The Sovereign's Gambit
books.description: A timeless treatise on political intrigue and power struggles, told through the rise and fall of a cunning leader in a fictional empire.

books.title: Echoes of the Unseen
books.description: An exploration of eerie landscapes and haunting phenomena, weaving stories that blur the boundaries between reality and imagination.

books.title: Mind's Liberation
books.description: A transformative guide to overcoming personal struggles, cultivating resilience, and embracing a life of freedom and purpose.

books.title: Quantum Myths and Realities
books.description: A riveting exploration of quantum mechanics and its philosophical implications, challenging readers to rethink the fabric of reality.

books.title: Labyrinths of the Mind
books.description: An enlightening guide to understanding human cognition, decision-making, and the psychological traps that shape our lives.

books.title: Dreamers of Tomorrow
books.description: A thought-provoking look at innovation and perseverance, told through the stories of visionaries who dared to dream beyond their time.

books.title: The Art of Leadership
books.description: A practical guide to building effective teams, motivating individuals, and leading with integrity in times of change and challenge.

books.title: Trials of the Shadow Realm
books.description: A surreal journey through a mysterious shadow world, where a man must unravel its secrets to save his own soul.

books.title: Leaves of the Forgotten Galaxy
books.description: An intricate narrative exploring the forgotten tales of a galaxy on the brink of rediscovery, weaving together myth and mystery.

books.title: The Riddle of Cain
books.description: A cryptic puzzle leads a group of adventurers on a treacherous journey, uncovering dark secrets that change their world forever.

books.title: Desert Chronicles: Ascension
books.description: The saga continues as the desert planet’s inhabitants rise to reclaim their legacy amidst chaos and intrigue.

books.title: Children of the Ember
books.description: Amidst the ruins of an ancient civilization, a new generation discovers their inherited power to reshape the world.

books.title: Eclipse of Eternity
books.description: As a celestial phenomenon threatens the galaxy, an unlikely band of heroes must unite to preserve existence itself.

books.title: Heralds of the New Dawn
books.description: Amid a crumbling empire, whispers of a new beginning challenge the order of a stagnant society.

books.title: Whispers of Eldritch Tides
books.description: An eerie account of a town's descent into madness after an ancient artifact washes ashore, awakening eldritch horrors.

books.title: Chronicles of the Eternal Flame
books.description: A mythical collection of stories from an ancient realm where the Eternal Flame holds the key to unlocking the secrets of the universe.

books.title: Adventures of the Hidden Vale

books.title: Tales of Shadows and Stars
books.description: A captivating anthology of stories that traverse love, mystery, and the cosmos, where every tale shines with its own unique brilliance.

books.title: Echoes of Thought

books.title: Remote Horizons

books.title: Shadows of Transformation

books.title: Journeys of a Modern Mind

Good book!
Awesome book! This is a must read!
Great book! I loved it!
Good book! I believe it could be better.
Awesome book! I think it's the best book I've ever read!
Great book! Well I think it's a must read!
Good book! But not the best. I expected more.
Awesome book! I loved it! I think it's the best book I've ever read!
Best book about physics!
Best book about Brutalist Architecture! I loved it!
This is a huge, thick book with a ton of information - a must read book for all architects! Great photos and descriptions!
This is the only book to thoroughly document the world's finest examples of Brutalist architecture. I loved it! I think it's the best book I've ever read!
I didn't like it. I expected more.
Not the best. I expected more.
Well it was a waste of time. I didn't like it.
This was not what I expected. I hoped for more.
If this book was a movie, I would rate it 2/10. I didn't like it.
This is EPIC book! I loved it!
This is the best book I've ever read! I loved it!

Awesome book! This dark, gritty, alienating, violent cyberpunk manga is really good. The artist Nihei is really gifted to draw buildings and he creates an empty world left with never ending growing buildings, metallic structures, and deadly creatures out to get you.
